Introduction

The Boskovich fourteen (14) step Process Safety Management (PSM) program provides information and procedures to prevent or minimize an accidental release of ammonia.  This program attempts to anticipate future problems by identifying, evaluating, and preventing failures of the processes that could result in a release of this chemical.  Every element of the PSM program applies to all units in the process

Boskovich Farms, Inc. owns and operates a refrigeration facility to cold treat and store produce (fresh vegetables) and manufacture ice. Anhydrous ammonia is used as a refrigerant in the refrigeration systems.   In addition, an Aqua Ammonia Absorption Refrigeration Plant (AAARP) located on the north-east corner of property, which is owned and operated by Sithe Energies, Inc. also supplies refrigeration capacity to Boskovich.

The facility is in operation seven days per week, 24 hours per day.  Watchmen are present at all times.

The ammonia refrigeration facility consists of ten connected/or separate units as listed in Table 1.

The term "employees" refers to all workers of the units listed in Table 1 above.


Hazards of Ammonia

Anhydrous Ammonia, chemical symbol NH3, is third in terms of volume of chemicals produced in the United States. Ammonia is used for fertilizer production and is a common industrial refrigerant.  At atmospheric temperatures and pressures, ammonia is a colorless gas with a sharp, intensely irritating odor.  Depending on the concentration and duration of exposure, the health effects of ammonia gas can range from mild to severe irritation to the lining of the nose, throat, eyes, and lungs.  Inhalation of concentrations above 1000 ppm may injure the lungs with potentially fatal results.  Due to its low odor threshold of 5 ppm, ammonia has very good A?warning propertiesA?.  The A?level of concernA?, EPRG-2, is 200 ppm. At this concentration it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or otherwise serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individualA?s ability to take protective action.  

Process Chemistry

Ammonia is used strictly as a refrigerant at the Boskovich site.  There are no chemical reactions that occur in a closed loop mechanical refrigeration system.  Ammonia is used only as a heat transfer medium.  The ammonia liquid from the refrigeration system(s) is vaporized as it absorbs heat from the process, in this case produce cooling.  Ammonia vapor is returned to the refrigeration(s) system where it is compressed, cooled and condensed back into the liquid phase.  It is then sent back to the process to repeat the cooling cycle.

Process Technology and Equipment

Aqua Ammonia Absorption Refrigeration Plant (AAARP) - the function of the AAARP is to obtain refrigeration by steam.   Steam is sent to the re-boiler to heat a concentrated solution of ammonia in water.  This drives off the ammonia to be rectified to high quality anhydrous ammonia in the rectification column.  The ammonia vapor is then liquefied under pressure changing the state of the product from vapor to liquid.  The expanded ammonia is absorbed in the weak aqueous solution that enters the absorbers.  The absorbers combine a weak aqueous solution with ammonia vapor to produce a strong aqueous solution that is pumped back to the re-boiler to start the cycle over again.  Detailed Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams (P&ID) showing the location of the AAARP are kept on-site.

Refrigeration, Ice Making Units, Coolers, Freezers, Hydrocoolers A? Refrigeration can be accomplished by either running the AAARP system or by operating Boskovich FarmsA? refrigeration systems.  When running the refrigeration systems, the suction gas from the liquid recirculator or accumulator flows to the compressor.  The high-pressure, high-temperature gas from the compressor flows to evaporative condensers condensing the gas into a liquid.  The high pressure liquid drains into the high-pressure receiver.  The receiver top is equalized to the common discharge header of each evaporative condenser.  This maintains the pressure in the receiver to the inlet pressure of the condensers.  The high-pressure liquid from the receiver flows to the recirculator or accumulator to separate the refrigerant liquid from the suction vapor.  The liquid is held in the vessel until it is returned to the evaporators via pump or gravity.

The refrigeration system capacity is automatically controlled by measuring the suction pressure.  When the pressure increases, the compressor capacity is increased, when the pressure decreases, the compressor capacity is reduced.

If the system is run on the AAARP system, the liquid valve from the AAARP would feed ammonia to the liquid recirculator on demand.  Detailed P&ID for each refrigeration unit are kept on-site.  Drawings showing the location of the AAARP are kept on site.

Hydrovac Tube Pre-cooling Unit A? The low pressure pump accumulator is attached by piping to a refrigeration compression and condensing unit.  This unit is a custom design, flat-bed semi-truck trailer that has the compressors, condensing tower, and high pressure receiver mounted on the trailer.  The tube, low-pressure accumulator, and compressing trailer is easily disassembled and transportable.  The system is designed to be rugged.  A detailed P&ID is kept on-site. 


Employee Involvement

The intent of this procedure is to involve employees at an elemental level of the PSM Plan. The purpose of employee participation is improved safety for all employees. Process Safety Management will not be effective without the involvement of the employees and/or their representatives.  Boskovich Farms, Inc. provides for employee participation in their process safety management plans by consulting with employees in developing the PSM program. 

Awareness

Each new refrigeration employee is made aware of ammonia refrigeration PSM as a part of their initial orientation process, in conjunction with hazards communication required by 29 CFR 1910.1200. New refrigeration employees are given a document titled Hazards of Ammonia and a one page document entitled Process Safety Management.  The PSM document is a simple explanation of what the Process Safety Management program for ammonia refrigeration is all about.  It is reviewed with each new refrigeration employee and they acknowledge their awareness of PSM by signing the document.  If necessary, the PSM orientation is given in Spanish.  PSM awareness documents are available in both English and in Spanish.

Involvement

Boskovich Farms, Inc. involves operations or maintenance employees in meetings or discussions concerning the PSM policies and procedures.  In addition, several other PSM procedures are reviewed by or conducted with the involvement of at least one employee or a representative of the employees:

A?    Process Safety Information is reviewed for accuracy and thoroughness.
A?    Operating Procedures are developed with input from refrigeration employees. In addition, refrigeration employees check the written procedures to ensure they are accurate.
A?    Training programs and needs for refresher training are reviewed with affected employees. More experienced refrigeration employees participate in the training process by observing the demonstration of job tasks conducted by the less experienced employees.
A?    Pre-Startup Safety Reviews are conducted with involvement of at least one refrigeration employee.
A?    Mechanical Integrity Audits are conducted with the involvement of at least one refrigeration employee.
A?    Refrigeration employees participate in the development of the mechanical integrity program and procedures.
A?    All affected refrigeration employees are made aware of ammonia refrigeration process changes prior to commencement of work. 
A?    Incident Investigation reports are reviewed with all affected refrigeration employees. An employee may be asked to serve on the investigation team.
A?    Emergency Planning and Response procedures are reviewed with affected employees.

Boskovich Farms, Inc. also provides a means of allowing employees to voice concerns about process safety to management. To meet this provision, we have established a management system to address, resolve, follow-up and document employee concerns.  This management system includes provisions to:

A?    Assure that the concerns are resolved in a timely manner.
A?    Document the actions that are to be taken to resolve the concerns.
A?    complete the actions as soon as possible; when necessary, interim measures are taken when the
A?    Actions will require significant time to implement.
A?    Develop a written schedule of when actions are to be completed.
A?    Monitor the implementation of the actions and verify and document their completion.
A?    communicate the actions to operating, maintenance, and other employees whose work
A?    Assignments are in the process and who may be affected by the recommendations or actions.

Access to Information

Refrigeration employees, including contractor refrigeration employees, are provided access to the process hazard analyses (PHA) and any other information required by the PSM Standard.  They have access to all Process Safety Information, including:

A?    piping and instrumentation drawings
A?    equipment information
A?    chemical information such as MSDS
A?    technological information such as process chemistry
A?    operating and maintenance procedures

The Environmental Compliance manager is responsible for controlling access to PSM information. All affected employees are provided access to ammonia refrigeration PSM files and information at all times (not just during day shift) but access is available under the following limitations:

A?    Approval must be given to remove any documents from the file.
A?    Original copies of documents are not to be removed from the file area.
A?    No markings are be made on original documents.
A?    Previously unfiled documents are only added with proper authorization.

All employees directly involved with operation and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration system are encouraged to periodically review the process safety information and most recent process hazard analysis.  Such reviews are considered to be a training activity and can be conducted on company time.

Process Hazard Analysis

The Process Safety Management Standard requires employers to perform a process hazard analysis (PHA) for each covered ammonia refrigeration process. The purpose of performing a PHA is to identify and analyze the significance of potential hazards associated with the process and to provide information to assist employers in making decisions for improving safety and reducing the chances of a catastrophic ammonia release.
The PHA addressed the following:
A?    The hazards of the process.
A?    Previous incidents with likely potential for catastrophic consequences.
A?    Consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls.
A?    Engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards and their interrelationships.
A?    Facility siting.
A?    Human factors.
A?    A qualitative evaluation of a range of possible safety and health effects of failure of controls on employees in the workplace.
The process hazard analysis was performed by teams with expertise in engineering and process operations, knowledgeable in the specific PHA methodology used, and included employees with experience and knowledge specific to the processes being evaluated.  The most recent analysis was completed in May 2009.

Operating Procedures

The intent of these procedures is to provide clear instructions for conducting activities involved in handling ammonia that are consistent with the process safety information. The operating procedures address steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions.

Training

The intent of this procedure is to help employees understand the nature and causes of problems arising from ammonia operations, and increase employee awareness with respect to their hazards. An effective training procedure significantly reduces the number and severity of incidents arising from process operations, and can be instrumental in preventing small problems from leading to a catastrophic release. The training procedures include: Initial Training, Refresher Training, and Documentation.

Contractors

The intent of this procedure is to establish a screening process so that contractors, hired and used, accomplish the desired job tasks involving ammonia without compromising the safety and health of employees at a facility. The contractor must assure that contract employees are trained on performing the job safely, on the hazards related to the job, and on applicable provisions of the emergency action plan.

Pre-Startup Safety Review

The intent of this procedure is to make sure that, for new facilities and for modified facilities when the modification necessitates a change to process safety information, important considerations are addressed before ammonia introduced into the process; namely, the pre-startup safety review must confirm the following: construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications; safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and adequate; for new facilities, a PHA has been performed and recommendations resolved or implemented; modified facilities meet the requirements of paragraph (1), "Management of Change"; and training of each employee involved in the process has been completed.

New Facilities or Systems

Because a process hazard analysis must be performed before the startup of a new facility or system, all required process safety information will be compiled and readily available. This includes information concerning the hazards of ammonia, the technology of the process, and the equipment in the process.  The process hazard analysis shall be in full compliance with the requirements of 1910.119, paragraph (e). All recommendations from the process hazard analysis must be either resolved or implemented prior to startup, and properly documented. 

Documentation will be established to verify completion of this activity. Boskovich will ensure that:

A?    All safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are written, implemented, and are adequate. Recognized standards or codes, manufacturersA? instructions, and other applicable regulations, may be considered in drafting procedures. 
A?    Construction and equipment is in accordance with the design specifications. The construction codes and standards used must be documented in the process safety information.
A?    Training for each employee involved in operating the process has been completed. The modifications or additions reflected in the PSSR may create a need for additional training in other areas such as maintenance, emergency response or HAZCOM.  
A?    Changes or revisions in the process safety information, the PHA and operating proceduresA?like all other required PSM documents A? must be available to employees.

Modified Facilities or Systems

All process safety information must be updated. Boskovich will ensure that:

A?    The requirements for a Management of Change have been completed. The Management of Change shall be in substantial compliance with the requirements of 1910.119, Paragraph (l). 
A?    The relevant safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place and adequate. All procedures shall follow, where applicable, recognized standards or codes, manufacturersA? instructions, and other applicable regulations. 
A?    Construction and equipment is in accordance with the design specifications. 
A?    Training for each employee involved in operating the new equipment in the process has been completed. The modifications reflected in the PSSR may create a need for additional training in other areas such as maintenance, emergency or HAZCOM. Training for employees operating a process that has been modified will include reviewing any changes to relevant procedures. 
A?    Startup of new equipment is conducted in accordance with applicable industry standards, manufacturersA? recommendations, and plant procedures.

Verification Forms

A Pre-Startup Safety Review Verification form will be used to sign off acceptance of the pre-startup safety Review.  The form must be signed by the Operations Manager and the Refrigeration Engineer.

Mechanical Integrity

The intent of this procedure is to assure that equipment used to process, store, or handle ammonia is designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to minimize the risk of ammonia releases. A mechanical integrity program is in place to assure the continued integrity of ammonia equipment.  A maintenance schedule was compiled to track and log the process.

Hot Work Permit

The intent of this procedure is to control, in a consistent manner, non-routine work conducted in ammonia process areas. Specifically, this subparagraph is concerned with the permitting of hot work operations in process areas.

Hot work permits for hot work operations, such as the ones associated with welding and cutting conducted on or near an ammonia process, will be in compliance with the fire prevention and protection requirements of 29 CFR 1910.252(a).

Management of Change

The intent of this procedure is to require management of all modifications to equipment, procedures, raw materials and processing conditions concerning ammonia other than "replacement in kind," by identifying and reviewing them prior to implementation.

Incident Investigations

An incident investigation will be performed any time there is an incident which results in, or which could reasonably have resulted in (near-miss), a catastrophic release of ammonia. A catastrophic release can be defined as a major uncontrolled emission, fire, or explosion involving ammonia that presents serious danger to employees, including contract employees working on-site.

The following is a list of the criteria that will be used to determine whether an incident investigation should be performed. (Note: In the case of a near-miss, judgment must be made as to the potential results as opposed to the actual results.)

A? Quantity of Ammonia Released 
A? Property Damage 
A? Fire or Explosion 
A? Injuries or Deaths 

Emergency Planning and Response

The intent of this procedure is to address actions employees are to take when there is and unwanted release of ammonia.  Boskovich Farms Inc. has prepared an Emergency Response Plan for this facility.  The plan is documented in Section 6 of the Risk Management Plan (RMP).

Compliance Audits

Boskovich Farms, Inc. has developed a compliance audit program to verify implementation of all PSM elements. The audits are conducted at least every three years. A Compliance Audit Checklist will be used to conduct and document the audit.  

The Refrigeration Engineer performs the audits on the ammonia facilities and verifies that the audit records are included in the PSM Files.  A written report of the audit findings is prepared.  Responses to the audit findings are promptly addressed and documented, and any deficiencies found during the audit promptly corrected.  Once the audit form is completed, the appropriate actions to address the recommendations are taken and documented.

SECTION 1



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 



Boskovich Farms, Inc. is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers such areas as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  This program has been prepared pursuant to Part 68 of Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations.



This RMP is prepared for the Boskovich Farms, Inc. facility located at 711 Diaz Avenue, Oxnard, California.  The facility is a produce preparation, storage, and distribution facility which operates various ammonia refrigeration systems to cool vegetable or fruit as food produce prior to distribution.  Boskovich Farms, Inc. has approximately 34,600 pounds of anhydrous ammonia refrigerant at the site in several refrigeration systems including portable HydroVac units, the Hydrocooler, two ice machines, and the main refrigeration systems for the cooler buildings.



In July 1993 Boskovich Farms, Inc. prepared a Process Safety Management (PSM) Plan and a Risk Management and Prevention Program (RMPP).  The documents have been updated periodically as required.  These documents are referenced by this RMP because they contain some of the elements required by the EPA for the RMP.



Boskovich Farms, Inc. designates Steven Marquez as the Compliance Officer.  Mr. Marquez has the responsibility to plan, organize, implement, monitor and control the associated risks of our hazardous materials management.  All records associated with the prevention program elements are retained for a minimum of five years unless otherwise specified in the CalARP regulation.



1.1     ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE



To prevent the accidental release of ammonia, Boskovich Farms, Inc. has developed the following:

Maintenance and inspection procedures to ensure the equipment is properly maintained and functioning properly.

 

Standard operating procedures to ensure that equipment operation minimizes the possibility of an ammonia release.

Employee training so that operators know the proper use of the equipment and that non-operators are aware of the dangers of ammonia and the necessary steps to undertake in the event of an ammonia release.

The facility is secured by fencing around the site and a 24-hour guard to minimize the possibility of a third party damaging equipment or by other means causing a release of the ammonia.



The programs are contained in Binder 1, Risk Management and Prevention Program.  Boskovich Farms, Inc. has prepared an Emergency Response Plan to respond to ammonia releases.  In general the plan includes:

A list of safety equipment available at the facility;

Response procedures for minor leaks;

Response procedures for major leaks;

Agency notification procedures; and

Emergency procedures.



A copy of the Emergency Response Plan (ERP) can be found in Binder 1, RMPP, Section 10.  Further description of the ERP is contained in Section 6 of the RMP.



1.2     STATIONARY SOURCE AND SUBSTANCE HANDLED



Boskovich Farms, Inc. operates several ammonia cooling systems that cool food produce prior to storage and shipment.  These systems contain an approximate aggregate 34,600 pounds of  anhydrous ammonia.



1.3     ACCIDENTAL RELEASE SCENARIOS



The Worst Case Scenario is the release of 1,725 pounds of liquid ammonia from one of the refrigeration accumulators (vessel) on one of the ice machines.  This scenario is considered very improbable and would result in offsite impacts with a calculated Toxic Endpoint of 0.6 mile.  The Alternate Scenario considers a leaking valve.  This is a scenario that is moderately probable but should not result in offsite consequences.



In order to reduce the distance to the toxic endpoint from an accidental release the followi

ng administrative controls and mitigation measures are in place at Boskovich Farms, Inc.

System operation and emergency response training

Routine maintenance schedule and procedures

Written operating procedures

Ammonia detection sensors promote early warning of a release

Security personnel who monitor the facility to prevent unauthorized personnel on site.



Details regarding the offsite consequence analysis for the worst case and alternative release scenarios can be found in Section 3.



1.4     GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



Components of this RMP are as follows.

Registration

Offsite Consequence Analysis

Five-year Accident History

Program 2 Prevention Program

Program 3 Prevention Program

Emergency Response

Certification

Update Procedure



Risk management components of the program are as follows.

Maintenance and standard operating procedures for the ammonia systems

The site is prevented from being accessed by trespassers with the use of fencing and on-site security personnel

Emergency response plan

Training for employees

Incident investigation documentation and procedures

Automatic system shutdowns

Windsocks for direction of wind visible on-site and from neighboring property

Ammonia sensors at various location at the facility



1.5     FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Boskovich Farms, Inc. has had no ammonia release incidents since the incident reported, via eSubmit, on June 30, 2008.  



1.6     EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN



The Emergency Response Plan (ERP) for this facility, provided here in Section 5, has appropriate information for responding to an ammonia release.  The general emergency response policy for an ammonia release is to:

Determine the severity and point of the release following the assessment form in the ERP.

Evacuate non-emergency response personnel to a safe area.

For minor leaks, isolate and/or fix the leak.

Notify the appropriate personnel and CUPA, Oxnard Fire Department.

esults in, or which could reasonably have resulted in (near-miss), a catastrophic release of ammonia. 4.1.6.3  Procedures



Boskovich Farms, Inc. initiates incident investigations as promptly as possible, but at least within 48 hours, and will establish a team including at least one person knowledgeable in the process, a contract employee if the incident involved a contract employer's work, and other personnel with the knowledge and experience to thoroughly investigate and analyze the incident. A report including the date of the incident, the date the investigation began, a description of the incident, factors that contributed to the incident, and any recommendations resulting from the investigation. 



Boskovich Farms, Inc. has established a system to address and resolve the team's findings and recommendations and document the resolutions and corrective actions taken.  In addition, the report will be reviewed with affected personnel, including contract employees, whose job tasks are relevant to the incident findings and will be retained for at least five years.  



The following sections outline the steps and procedures we will take to meet the requirements listed above.



4.1.6.4  Initial Incident Response



    The relative priority of response to a serious incident should be:

    Providing medical and other safety and health assistance to personnel.

    Bringing the incident under control.

Determining whether any notifica

tion must be made to a governmental agency (OSHA,   EPA, DOT, etc.).

Directing activities related to the investigation in a way that preserves relevant information and evidence.



    Activities to preserve information may include:

    Securing and barricading the scene when appropriate.

    Photograph the scene and effected assets.

    Initiating the collection of transient information.

    Preliminary interviewing of witnesses and personnel, etc.



A key element of this phase of the investigation is to get an accurate list of witnesses of all kinds that will need to be interviewed in greater detail by the investigation team. Another important part of the initial response is to take photographs which may prove useful as the investigation continues. This is critical if the scene must be disturbed before the investigation team can complete its review.  Responsibility for this early phase of incident response should rest with an incident commander.



4.1.6.5  Incident Investigation Team



Timing is of the essence in forming the investigation team. The OSHA standard requires the team to begin its investigation as soon as possible, but no later than 48 hours following the incident [OSHA 29CFR 1910.119 (m)(2)]. In addition, there should be no unnecessary delay between the initiation and the completion of an incident investigation.  Boskovich Farms, Inc. will select the members of the Incident Investigation Team (hereafter referred to as the Team). The exact membership of the Team will be dependent upon severity, complexity, and circumstances surrounding the incident. 



A multi-disciplinary team is required to perform the incident investigation.  The team must consist of at least one person knowledgeable in the process involved, including a contract employee if the incident involved the work of the contractor, and other persons with appropriate knowledge and experience to thoroughly investigate and analyze the incident.



A Team Leader will be designated. The Team Leader's d

uties include:

 

Controlling the scope of team activities by identifying which lines of investigation should be pursued, referred to another group for study, or deferred.

Calling and presiding over meetings.

Assigning tasks and establishing timetables.

Ensuring that no potentially useful data source is overlooked.

Keeping the employer advised of the progress of the investigation.

 



The Team has full access to the site, document files and to all employees who may have input to the investigation process.



4.1.6.6  Safety Information, Hazard Review, Operationg/Maintenance Procedures, or Training



A prompt and comprehensive search for facts surrounding the incident is the first major undertaking of the Team.  The Team may conduct the following types of activities as it performs its fact-finding function.  Team members should visit the incident scene before physical evidence has been disturbed. The Team Leader is responsible for ensuring that the Team is not exposing team members to any dangers as the visit is conducted.  Personal safety of the team members should take priority over the incident investigation process at all times. 



Team members may first review the scene individually, discuss their preliminary findings, and then repeat the process as a group with a designated individual preparing a written log of observations and important comments.



Some of the things that may be noted during the scene visit are:

 

Indication of any unusual activities in the area (welding or cutting equipment, tools, motorized equipment, etc.).

Status of safety equipment in area (Was equipment used? Was it readily available? Any indications of safety equipment problems?).

Positions of important valves and controls that could have contributed to the incident or which may have been used to control the incident.

Any indications of fire or explosion damage and whether any combustible materials were involved.

Whether vessels, piping, etc. in the area were properly la

beled and identified.

 



The Team may prepare visual aids such as photographs, sketches and graphical representations of information that may be useful during the investigation.  The Team may take brief statements from any eyewitnesses who are available during the inspection of the scene. More detailed interviews may be arranged later. It is a good practice to interview each witness alone. The witness should be more candid and less likely to be influenced by the statements of other witnesses.



The Team should determine whether any key mechanical equipment should be disassembled (if possible) and should then observe such disassembly and record findings. Any equipment which may have failed or otherwise may have contributed to the incident should be preserved and/or carefully documented. The Team may review all sources of potentially useful information such as as-built drawings, operating logs, records, charts, previous reports, standard and emergency procedures, equipment manuals, oral instructions, change records, training and performance records of employees, laboratory tests, etc..  Moreover, the Team should consider whether any sampling or forensic analysis should be conducted.  The Team may carefully document all sources of information gathered during the fact-finding process for inclusion in the incident investigation report.



4.1.6.7  Determine the Cause and/or Contributing Factors



Establishing the cause and the contributing factors of the incident is crucial to the development of effective recommendations to correct and prevent a recurrence.  Formal analysis of the cause will help to avoid making premature or erroneous judgments.  It is also important that the root cause of the incident, as well as contributing factors be identified. A recommended procedure for determining cause(s) of the incident follows:



The Team may develop the chronology of events which occurred before, during and after the incident. The focus of the chronology may be solely o

n what happened and what actions were taken. List alternatives when the status cannot be definitely established due to missing or contradictory information.



The Team may identify any conditions or circumstances which deviated from normal.  Identify all hypotheses of the causes of the incident based on these deviations.



The Team may test the various cause hypotheses against all available evidence and information, and list in order of likelihood. In each case establish what the root cause and secondary cause(s) was.  As a Team, strive to agree on the most likely root cause(s) and secondary cause(s).  (Reference the standard lists of contributing causes contained on the Incident Investigation Report Form.)



4.1.6.8  Recommend Corrective and Preventive Actions



During the determination of the cause process, some actions may surface that could have eliminated or reduced the chances for the incident having occurred. In some cases, these recommendations may not relate to the most likely cause but may still be an appropriate

recommendation to improve the safety of the process.  The Team will formalize these recommendations in two distinct areas. Engineering changes encompass those actions which include physical changes to the system hardware. Administrative changes include procedural changes, training, etc.



The Team may prioritize the implementation of corrective and preventive actions. If the Team recommends that changes should be made prior to resumption of operations, the report should include the recommended time frame for the change. In other situations, an approximate time frame for implementation may be included.  The Team's recommended changes may activate the management of change procedure if they go beyond replacements in kind. Once Boskovich Farms, Inc. management evaluates the recommendations and determines whether they will be implemented, the management of change procedures must be followed if required.



The recommended changes will be complete

d as soon as possible.  OSHA considers an employer to have resolved recommendations when the employer has either adopted the recommendations or justifiably declined to do so. An employer can justifiably decline to adopt a recommendation where it can document that:

 

information which was not known by incident investigation team members becomes available at a later date and eliminates the need for the recommendation. Note that the initial incident investigation may have to be updated to reflect the additional information;

the recommendation is not necessary to protect the health of employees or contractors;

an alternative measure would provide a sufficient level of protection; or,

the recommendation is not feasible.



Rejection of recommendations should be communicated to the Team and any subsequent recommendations must also be resolved.

5.9          ESTABLISHMENT OF OBJECTIVES AND PRIORITIES FOR RESPONSE



5.9.1     Establish Emergency Operations Center (EOC)

 

This facility has established an emergency operations center (EOC) to serve as the command center from which all emergency response activities are coordinated. The EOC is located in the operations office. The back-up EOC is located in the corporate office. The back-up EOC will be used in the event that the primary EOC is unusable for any reason.



The EOC is activated at the discretion of the ERC or his alternate. The EOC should be activated for all emergencies meeting any of the following criteria:

 

Extended, on-going release of a hazardous material;

Release of a hazardous material resulting in injuries to facility personnel;

Release of a hazardous material causing, or potentially causing, an off-site impact;

Incidents resulting in the need to coordinate the activities of local, state or federal response agencies or an outside contractor; and,

        Incidents where the response activities are expected to continue beyond a 2 - 3 hour time period.

 



The ERC will activate the EOC after making an initial assessment of the incident. If the EOC is activated, the emergency response team members are instructed by the emergency telephone operator or using the intercom system to gather at that location. The ERC will direct all emergency response activities from the EOC. 



Upon notification of an emergency, the emergency respons

e team members will report immediately to the Emergency Operations Center. The emergency response team will follow the direction of the ERC in responding to the emergency. If the ERC has not yet arrived on-site, the area supervisor will lead the team.



The ERC, or his designee, will remain in the EOC throughout the duration of the incident. This will help ensure proper and effective implementation of the emergency response procedures by making the ERC immediately available and reachable to make the necessary decisions. 



The ERC will be equipped with appropriate communications equipment and information necessary for proper implementation of the plan.



5.9.2        Set Immediate Goals and Objectives



The main objective of the initial response by the emergency response team will be to determine the extent of the incident, particularly regarding any possible personnel injuries.  The following provides an approximate order of priority for responding to emergencies:

 

Response to personnel injuries

Stopping leak/discharge

Containment of leak/discharge

Corporate notification

Notification to governmental agencies

Spill clean-up/decontamination

 



Operation of the EOC should allow several of these priorities to occur simultaneously.



5.9.3      Specify Mitigating Actions



Once the immediate goals and objectives are established, a tactical plan should be developed which specifies the mitigating actions which are needed. The tactical plan should address the following questions:

 

Does the area need to been evacuated?

Do hot and cold zones need to be established in the area?

Does anyone need to be rescued from the area?

Will anyone require medical attention?

What corrective actions should be taken which will contain, control, or stop the emergency conditions?

What company personnel, off-site responders, or government agencies should be contacted?

 



Mitigating actions must be tailored to the type of hazard present. For example, containment might be appli

cable for an oil spill (e.g., use of booming strategies) but would not be appropriate for an ammonia gas release. The facility is encouraged to develop checklists, flowcharts, and brief descriptions of actions to be taken to control different types of incidents.



Annex 3 contains procedures for handling specific emergencies which could occur at the facility. These procedures and page 1 of the ERC's checklist should be consulted when developing the tactical plan.
